Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Investigating the Interplay between Language and Cognition in American Sign Language Referential Cohesion

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Language users must constantly choose between different linguistic forms that refer to the same entity, such as 'he', 'Henry' or 'the man.' How do speakers choose which form to use? In spoken languages, this choice is largely determined by grammatical and information structural factors such as the previous grammatical role of the entity and whether the entity is the topic under discussion. This dissertation research asks whether pronoun usage in sign languages follows grammatical or gestural rules. American Sign Language (ASL) pronouns, which are points, are thought to get their meaning from ad hoc associations between entities and the space the signer points to. A point towards a space associated with a man named Henry is equivalent to the pronoun 'he' in English. By contrast, a pointing sign towards a space where no entity has been previously associated is predicted to be meaningless. This view suggests that ASL pronouns are primarily spatial associations between entities and signing space, which are not necessarily chosen based on principles of grammar or information structure. Two experiments test whether ASL pronominal forms follow the grammatical patterns of spoken languages. The experiments investigate how ASL signers refer to entities in contexts that vary in spatial associations and the number of possible entities being talked about.

This research will inform our understanding of whether choice of referring expressions is guided by universal or language specific principles. This knowledge can directly contribute to improving education of deaf children who on average have much lower literacy skills than hearing children. By developing a model for how ASL creates referential links between sentences, the project will provide the means to help signing children to understand the parallel processes in English text.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Researchers in linguistics and psychology have long been interested in how speakers decide which referring expression (e.g.  'the man', 'he') to use in different linguistic contexts, and how hearers and readers are able to understand such expressions when they are potentially ambiguous (e.g. 'John chatted with Peter because he...'). Studies of English, have found that more specific expressions ('the man') are used by speakers when describing an entity that is new to the discourse, while less specific ones are used when the entity has been talked about before ('he'). Other studies have found that English speakers' choice to use a pronoun is governed by information-structural factors, such as whether or not the entity referred to was the subject in the previous sentence. Comprehenders, on the other hand, have to reverse-engineer who the speaker could have meant when using a pronoun. They do this by integrating information about who the speaker was likely to be talking about, based on the discourse context that the pronoun occurred in, and on how probable it is that the speaker would use a pronoun to talk about that entity, given their preference for pronominalizing previous subjects. Findings from other studies show that such principles generally can account for the behavior of language producers and language comprehenders in languages other than English as well.

            An understudied question, however, is how well spoken language models can account for the behavior of producers and comprehenders in sign languages. This dissertation work examined referential cohesion in one sign language, American Sign Language (ASL), looking specifically at the contribution of factors unique to sign languages, such as the use of the space around the signer, and of factors found in spoken language referential cohesion. Sign languages can make use of the space surrounding the signer in order to make clear who does what to whom. For example, when an ASL signer uses a pronoun, she can point to an area of signing space, which she has previously linked to an entity. When signing 'John chatted with Peter because he...'  the signer can associate John with the space on her right side, and Peter with the space on her left. Then, for the pronoun, the signer can point at the space previously associated with either John or Peter, making it clear whom she is talking about. This makes ASL pronouns seem quite unlike English pronouns, both because ASL pronouns are made unambiguous through this process, and because it appears to be necessary to have linked entities with areas of space in order to use a pronoun. Moreover, previous research has assumed that a specific type of discourse context that influences pronoun comprehension is unavailable in sign languages. This type of discourse context arises from a certain type of verb making it likely that the previous subject will be mentioned again.. However, previous research has claimed that this type of verb is not attested in sign languages, due to restrictions on grammar and meaning that are specific to the visual modality. This is expected to have an impact on the usefulness of such discourse context as a cue to resolving pronouns in ASL.

            Though a number of experiments, this dissertation found that while the unique properties of using a visual language exert some influence over how pronouns are used,  signers look just like speakers with respect to referential cohesion for the most part. Contrary to previous claims in the literature, signers use discourse context as a cue to who will be mentioned next, just as speakers do. Although one of the types of verb that invites re-mention of the previous subject is relatively rare, this type does exist, counter to expectation. For pronoun production, the findings show that ASL signers produce more pronouns when they are talking about entities that have been linked to areas of space, than about entities that have not. Nonetheless, they still use more pronouns than other referring expressions even when the entities have not been linked to areas of space. For pronoun comprehension, signers are sensitive to where the pronoun is directed, and therefore to whom it refers, but they also frequently disregard this information in favor of understanding the pronoun as referring to the entity that was the most likely to be talked about in the discourse, which is how pronouns are understood in spoken languages. Finally, ASL pronouns appear to be affected by information-structural factors. Signers have a limited preference for using and interpreting pronouns as previous sentential objects, but pronouns are used frequently for previous subjects as well, both in cases when only the subject is available (e.g. 'Lisa laughs because she...') and when both subject and object are available (e.g. 'Lisa likes Mary because she (=Lisa)...').
